job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Pennington, NJ
pros:
Great co-workers
Beautiful building
You'll see deer and other wildlife 
That's it for the Pros
cons:
Upper management is clueless on how to keep their staff
They keep buying more and more property but aren't taking care of the people in their current buildings
Poor staffing is everywhere right now but management is only focusing on getting new staff in, not retaining their experienced nurses. 
So, if you're a new nurse you'll be making as much as a VERY EXPERIENCED nurse but don't count on anyone with knowledge being able to help/teach you because we are all leaving or at least leaving the bedside cause management only cares about warm bodies NOT the people busting their butts taking care of patients! Come and get your year of hospital experience and leave like most people do. 
Only bonuses given are yearly frozen turkey (just like Shoprite gives) and a $300 "Thank you bonus" at the end of the year. 
Oh, and you'll be told REPEATEDLY how lucky you are to still have a job during a worldwide pandemic!

pros: Decent pay. Nice people. Very clean environment. Life saving

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Hopewell, NJ
pros: A lot of positive things
cons: None that I can think of

pros:
- Competitive wages
- Small system so you get to know everyone
cons:
- Very little focus on the inpatient hospital staff. Capital health is expanding and buying outpatient offices but lack staffing and focus on inpatient.
- The nurse to patient ratio is 1:5-6 on all floors (medsurg, tele, oncology, surgical)
- Nurses get pulled across campuses without any orientation on the other hospital
- Very little recognition from upper management or hospital board. 
- Poor staff retention
- Poor treatment of CNAs and Techs. Bonuses are offered to nurses for picking up extra shifts but no incentives for other staff.

pros: The coworkers truly pull together and help each other out during good and rough days. Teamwork and camaraderie have kept many of us there for years.
cons: It can get very busy and sometimes caseload and/or acuity is intense.

review_title: Good experience but toxic work environment
job_title: Emergency/Critical Care Technician in Trenton, NJ
pros: You learn a lot here from the wide variety of cases that walk through the door. Inner city, level two trauma center means you see interesting stuff like TB, unusual infectious diseases, crazy traumas. You learn how to deal with common emergencies too like MIs, stroke, and codes.
cons: Very toxic work environment. Lot of gossip and talking behind each others backs.

review_title: Grass is not always greener...RN beware
pros:
1. Located just off of I-295.
2. Job security. Administration has no clue how to retain their own nurses, therefore, there is always a shortage of staff.
cons:
1. All RNs are pulled frequently including across 2 campuses without RN pool compensation. 
2. Charting system is NOT user friendly. All time consuming. Plan on staying late after your shift to finish your charting everyday.

pros: Great doctors, nurses and staff. The Capital Health Medical Group has a wonderful group of doctors.
cons: More employee recognition needed as large projects are completed under tight deadlines.

pros: Pay is decent, great healthcare benefits, can't beat pricing for prescriptions filled by hospital pharmacy. The cafeteria does respond to suggestions for improved variety of food offerings & tries to please all tastes.
cons: Unfortunately many staff have left my department. I reviewed CHS nearly 1 year ago; very little has changed --in fact has become worse. Sadly a new divisional director has increased the workload significantly, all the while spreading staff so thin that there are never enough crew on board to do our job properly with care. Any encouragement is solely about producing higher volume of work; not about providing quality care. Morale is very low and I am currently seeking employment elsewhere because I feel the system is broken & cannot be fixed.

review_title: Working at CH has been a roller coaster ride, but then again.. isn't that life?
job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist in Trenton, NJ
pros: Capital Health offers a competitive salary and benefits package. For the most part, my coworkers are supportive of each other and work as a team.  The equipment in my department is up-to-date and in some cases, state-of- the-art.
cons: In my department, there is favoritism towards certain employees. My particular supervisor does take kindly to suggestions for smoother workflow or other constructive criticism from subordinates. The purchasing department, at times, has caused inventory problems to the point where we could not do our work due to lack of supplies.

review_title: Pay Needs to be more competitive
pros:
Magnet Hospital 
Excellent nursing care
cons:
Pay is below average
-Nursing leadership/ administration needs a complete overhaul
-Nursing leadership is out of touch 
-Administration is reactionary versus proactive
- celebration of Nursing and nursing achievements lacks genuine thought and comes off as thrown together, rushed and done for show 
-

pros: The staff is an amazing group of people to work with.  The diverse backgrounds and skill sets everyone brings creates an amazing experience for staff & patients.  The relationships made with staff are the best part of the experience. The campus is beautiful as well, fairly new building from 2012.  We are starting to add a clinical ladder program. $1.50/hr more if you obtain a Certification in you specialty!!!
cons: Increased patient census and acuity of patients, with an  often decreased staff makes for a really challenging day.  Also, jobs keep being added to the nurses list of chores, without enough ancillary support.  The salary is not as competitive as most other hospitals nearby, however, they are working on catching us up.

review_title: Capital Health System believes in its professionals at all levels.
pros: All the people I work with are professional and down to earth.   Everyone tries to be positive even when times are tough.  Management is capable of making good decisions.  I believe that most of the people who work at CHS are there because they like what they do.  At the end of each day I feel that patients are well cared for.  I also feel the physicians are part of the "team" and want to work with the nurses in caring for the patients.
cons: Parking could be better.  A uniform store and a McDonald's on campus would be nice.  You lose unused sick time.

review_title: Used to be great place of employment, since move to new building it is cold & impersonal.
pros: Excellent benefits package, yearly pay increases, convenient scheduling for personal medical needs.
cons: They feel they own you. Excessive overtime expected, not necessarily asked for in advance. On call pay has never increased in 25 years of working here & you are expected to work another full shift after potentially being called in to work for 24 hours straight! Recently some benefits have been taken away due to financial concerns.

review_title: Impersonal, it's all about the money
pros: Hospitals in system have good reputation in the communities served, employees and middle management generally work hard to achieve organizational goals.  Salaries and benefits are competitive.
cons: Since opening new hospital, executive management has focused on money excessively and at the expense of its employees.  Workers (including middle management) who served the system's hospitals for many years were terminated despite their loyalty and dedication in order to maximize the reduction of salary dollars.  Many long-term physicians have been alienated by preferential treatment afforded to new docs perceived to be better money-makers.  Personnel decisions seem to be made in a cold, impersonal manner.

job_title: Business Development Assistant in Pennington, NJ
pros: I loved walking the halls of the hospital and seeing the same familiar faces each day. There's a very familial feeling with all the different doctors and offices housed in the building.
cons: Senior management can do no wrong and the HR processes to resolve an issue are archaic. If you have an issue with your boss, chances are you'll be the one paying for it. They'll never see so much as a slap on the wrist.

review_title: Working with Capital Health Systems was a very demanding and high paced place to work.
pros: Capital Health systems facilities were very clean, modern, and appealing. The facility was a very convenient place to work, because it was close to stores and restaurants. There was also ample parking for employees.
cons: Because it is such a convenient and pleasant place to go it quickly became very busy, very fast. It was too busy for the employees to keep up with. I was burned out after a year of working there.

pros: The people are really nice and good to work with. They pull together as a team.
cons: The downside to working with Capital Health is that there isn't much room for advancement. The management doesn't give you all the tools required to do job, they expect you to make do with what is available.

job_title: Mental Health Screener in Trenton, NJ
pros: Location is excellent. Subject matter is of great interest to me. Salary is fair.  Job tasks are completed by next shift so things are not left hanging.  C-Workers are pleasant, intelligent, caring and sensitive to patients and other employees needs.
cons: Large turnover rate. New staff is not as experienced in the Mental Health Field. Some do not seem willing to learn.

pros: Opportunity for growth, great people, rewarding at the end of the day.  Beautiful new facilility with great benefits for employees.
cons: Healthcare industry is becoming less and less lucrative for providers.  Capital Health does its best in the face of this adversity, however

pros: Strong Community Hospital dedicated to mission of delivering quality healthcare services to the community. Definitely a good “family feel” among employees. People genuinely care about each other and the way they do their jobs. Employees take great pride in their work and delivering the best care.
cons: You need to be a self starter, independent thinker, leader and ask questions.  Or, you could feels it not a good fit.

pros: Many long-term employees; strong focus on quality; ability for qualified employees to move up is supported; accreditation and credentials are valued.
cons: Pay rates are currently somewhat below market for the area; senior management makes decisions without seeking input from employees affected.

pros: Benefits are decent. Everyone is friendly and helpful. 75% of continuing Ed is paid for even new hires. After 10 years employment continuing Ed is free.
cons: It's very hard to get a raise, if you're lucky you'll get cost of living. Starting salary is competive but after that you're underpaid.
